Dear Ms. Klinski:
Attached is the Renewal Inspection Report for the above referenced facility completed on
07/19/21. Due to the violations, a written corrective action plan is required. It should be
noted that violations of any licensing statutes rules and are also violations of the MISEP
and your contract. The corrective action plan is due 15 days from the date of this letter
and must include the following:
 How compliance with each citation will be achieved.
 For repeat violations, note why the previous plan was unsuccessful.
 Who is directly responsible for implementing the corrective action for each
licensing statute and rule or section of the contract or MISEP citation.
 For repeat violations, why the prior CAP did not result in compliance.
 Specific time frames for each citation as to when the correction will be
completed or implemented.
 How continuing compliance will be maintained once compliance is
achieved.
 The signature of the responsible party and a date.
Upon receipt of an acceptable corrective action plan, a regular license will be issued. If
you fail to submit an acceptable corrective action plan, disciplinary action will result.

III. DESCRIPTION OF FINDINGS
1.) The facility is in compliance with all applicable rules and statutes except for the
following:
R 400.4113 Employee records.
An institution shall maintain employee records for each
employee and shall include documentation of all of the following
information prior to employment or at the time specified in this
rule:
(b) A true copy of verification of education from an accredited
college or university where minimum education requirements
are specified by rule.
(c) Verification of high school diploma or GED when
specified by rule.
(d) Work history.
(e) Three dated references which are obtained prior to
employment from persons unrelated to the employee and which
are less than 12 months old.
(f) A record of any convictions other than minor traffic
violations from either of the following entities:
(i) Directly from the Michigan state police or the
equivalent state law enforcement agency, Canadian province, or
other country where the person usually resides or has resided in
the previous 5 years,
(ii) From an entity accessing either Michigan state police
records or equivalent state, Canadian provincial, or other
country law enforcement agency where the person usually
resides or has resided in the previous 5 years.
(g) If the employee has criminal convictions, the institution
shall complete a written evaluation of the convictions that
addresses the nature of the conviction, the length of time since
the conviction, and the relationship of the conviction to regulated
activity for the purpose of determining suitability for employment
in the institution.
(h) A statement from the employee regarding any
convictions.
(i) Documentation from the Michigan department of human
services, the equivalent state or Canadian provincial agency, or
equivalent agency in the country where the person usually
resides, that the person has not been determined to be a
perpetrator of child abuse or child neglect. The documentation
shall be completed not more than 30 days prior to the start of
employment and every 12 months thereafter.
4

(j) A written evaluation of the employee's performance within
30 days of the completion of the probationary period or within
180 days, whichever is less, and a written evaluation of the
employee’s performance annually thereafter.
(b) One of two applicable new employee files reviewed was found not to have
verification of education. REPEAT VIOLATION, Interim Report, 10/13/20, and
CAP, 10/28/20, and Renewal Report, 08/12/19, and CAP, 08/13/19. The facility
must identify why the previous CAPs were unsuccessful.
(c) Four of 25 new employee files did not contain verification of high school
diploma/GED. REPEAT VIOLATION, Interim Report, 10/13/20, and CAP,
10/28/20, and Renewal Report, 08/12/19, and CAP, 08/13/19. The facility must
identify why the previous CAPs were unsuccessful.
(d) Two of 25 new employee files did not contain work history and another one was
a rehired employee, and the documentation was over a year old.
(e) Three of 25 new employee files did not contain all three references and another
one file was a rehired employee and the references were over a year old.
(f) Seven of 25 new employee files contained criminal clearances that were obtained
after hire; in one case the clearance was done five months after hire.
(g) Four of 31 employee files reviewed had criminal clearances with an adjudicated
crime requiring an employer assessment and there was not one in the file.
(h) Four of 31 employee files reviewed contained criminal clearances with an
adjudicated crime requiring an employee statement and there was not one in the file.
REPEAT VIOLATION, Interim Report, 10/13/20, and CAP, 10/28/20. The facility
must identify why the previous CAP was unsuccessful.
(i) 10 of 31 employee files reviewed were found to have late or missing initial and/or
annual central registry clearances. REPEAT VIOLATION, Interim Report, 10/13/20,
and CAP, 10/28/20, and Renewal Report, 08/12/19, and CAP, 08/13/19. The
facility must identify why the previous CAPs were unsuccessful.
(j) Three of 14 applicable employee files reviewed were found to have late or
missing performance appraisals. REPEAT VIOLATION, Interim Report, 10/13/20,
and CAP, 10/28/20, and Renewal Report, 08/12/19, and CAP, 08/13/19. The
facility must identify why the previous CAPs were unsuccessful.
R 400.4114 Tuberculosis screening for employees and volunteers.
The licensee shall document, prior to employment, that each
employee and volunteer who has contact with residents 4 or
more hours per week for more than 2 consecutive weeks is free
from communicable tuberculosis. Freedom from communicable
tuberculosis shall be verified within the 1-year period before
employment and shall be verified every 1 year after the last
verification or prior to the expiration of the current verification.
5

10 of 31 employee files reviewed were found to have missing tuberculosis
screenings. REPEAT VIOLATION, Interim Report, 10/13/20, and CAP, 10/28/20,
and Renewal Report, 08/12/19, and CAP, 08/13/19. The facility must identify
why the previous CAPs were unsuccessful.
R 400.4116 Chief administrator; responsibilities.
(1) An agency shall assign the chief administrator responsibility
for the on-site day-to-day operation of the institution and for
ensuring compliance with these rules.
During a review of previous corrective action plans (CAPs) as part of this inspection,
it was observed that the facility submitted a CAP for special investigation
2019C0219046 which indicated annual mandated reporter training would be
completed. During a review of employee files, it was noted that this has not
occurred. Six of six exiting employee files did not document the annual training. It is
the chief administrator’s duty to ensure CAPs are implemented. Technical
Assistance was provided in the 2019 Interim Report related to documentation of
training under R 128.
R 400.4120 Supervisor of direct care workers: qualifications.
A supervisor of direct care workers shall have 1 of the following:
(c) A high school diploma and 4 years of work experience in a
child caring institution.
Two of three new supervisor credentials reviewed for education and experience
were found not to meet the requirements of the rule. The two employees were
promoted to security supervisors, however, also function in a direct care supervisor
roll, therefore, must meet the rule requirements. Neither had the required experience
in a child caring institution.
R 400.4128 Initial staff orientation and ongoing staff training.
(3) The licensee shall document that each staff person whose
function is covered by these rules has participated in a minimum
of 50 clock hours of planned training within the first year of
employment and a minimum of 25 clock hours of training
annually thereafter related to the employee’s job function. At
least 16 of the 50 hours provided in the first year shall be
orientation provided prior to the assumption of duties.
6

Two of six existing employee files reviewed were found not to have 25 hours of
annual training. They had 20 and 22 respectively.
R 400.4128 Initial staff orientation and ongoing staff training.
(5) An employee shall not participate in restraining a resident or
placing a resident in seclusion prior to receiving training on
those topics. The training model shall be approved, in writing, by
the department.
One of six existing employee files reviewed was missing annual restraint training.
R 400.4152 Initial documentation.
At the time of admission, all of the following shall be in the
resident's case record:
(b) A photograph taken within the previous 12 months.
(f) Documentation of legal right to provide care.
(i) Documentation that the grievance policy was provided as
required in R 400.4132
(b) Two of six current resident files reviewed were noncompliant with having a photo
less than 12 months old. One of the two contained a photo that was not dated, and
the other file did not have a current photo. REPEAT VIOLATION, Interim Report,
10/13/20, and CAP, 10/28/20, and Renewal Report, 08/12/19, and CAP, 08/13/19.
The facility must identify why the previous CAPs were unsuccessful.
(f) Three of six current resident files did not contain documentation of the facility’s
legal right to provide care, i.e., the care management organization contract.
(i) One of six current resident files documented that the grievance policy
(provided/reviewed during orientation) was not done until 13 days after admission.
R 400.4153 Shelter care and detention institutions; preliminary service
plans.
Within 7 calendar days of admission, a plan shall be developed
for each resident. The plan shall include all of the following:
(c) The specific services to be provided by the institution.
(d) Other resources to meet the resident’s needs.
7

(c) and (d) The facility reported that they had not done detention work in a while but
began again about six months prior. The form they have for the seven-day plan does
not specifically address the requirements of the rule, therefore the information was
omitted. REPEAT VIOLATION, Interim Report, 10/13/20, and CAP, 10/28/20. The
facility must identify why the previous CAP was unsuccessful.
R 400.4154 Shelter care and detention institutions; service plans.
(1) Within 30 calendar days after admission and every 15
calendar days thereafter, an institution shall complete a written
service plan. The service plan shall include all of the following:
(a) The reason for continued care.
(b) Evaluation of service needs.
(c) Ongoing service needs.
(d) How service needs will be met.
(e) Unmet service needs and the reasons those needs are
unmet.
One of one detention file reviewed contained a 30-day plan that was one day late.
Additionally, the facility reported that they had not done detention work in a while but
began again about six months prior. The form they have for the plan does not
specifically address the requirements of the rule, therefore the information was not
sufficiently addressed and one area noting, ‘explain youth's participation/progress in
services’ was left blank.
R 400.4156 Institutions not detention institutions or shelter care
institutions; updated treatment plan.
(1) The social service worker shall complete, sign, and date an
updated treatment plan for each resident at least once every 90-
calendar days following the initial treatment plan.
Two of five applicable current resident files reviewed were found to have two late
and one missing updated treatment plans out of nine plans reviewed.
R 400.4166 Discharge plan.
(1) When a resident is discharged from institutional care, all of
the following information shall be documented in the case
record within 14 days after discharge:
(b) A brief summary or other documentation of the services
provided while in residence, including medical and dental
services.
8

(c) An assessment of the resident’s needs that remain to be
met.
(d) Any services that will be provided by the facility after
discharge.
(e) A statement that the discharge plan recommendations,
including medical and dental follow up that is needed, have
been reviewed with the resident and with the parent and with
the responsible case manager.
Two of four closed resident files reviewed was from the detention program and
contained a discharge plan document that did not contain the required information.
The facility reported that they had not done detention work in a while but began
again about six months prior. The form they have for the plan does not specifically
address the requirements of the rule, therefore the information was not sufficiently
addressed. One of four closed resident files reviewed did not document services that
will be provided by the facility after discharge. REPEAT VIOLATION, Interim
Report, 10/13/20, and CAP, 10/28/20, and Renewal Report, 08/12/19, and CAP,
08/13/19. The facility must identify why the previous CAPs were unsuccessful.
2.) Any violation listed in section 1 is also an MISEP violation. Please note that there
are additional MISEP requirements that may not be included in section 1. The
facility is in compliance will all additional MISEP requirements reviewed.
3.) Any violation listed in section 1 is also a DHHS Contract/Policy violation. Please
note that there are additional DHHS Contract/Policy requirements that may not be
included in section 1. The facility is in compliance will all additional DHHS
Contract/Policy requirements except for the following:
RFCJJ Contract Oct 17: 2.10.z. Page 27 Prison Rape Elimination Act &
Sexual Abuse Prevention & Response Overview:
4) Ensure all volunteers, employees, contractors, and other regular facility
visitors with resident contact have been screened in compliance with PREA
standards.
2 of 31 employee files reviewed did not contain documentation of PREA training
RFCJJ Contract Oct 17: 2.10.e.3.a Page 13 Annual Trauma Focused
Training: a) All program staff shall be provided with annual trauma-focused
program training to maintain a trauma-informed milieu and treatment
environment. Trauma-focused programming must be based on an
evidence-based, evidence-informed or promising practice treatment model.
Two of six applicable employee files did not contain documentation of annual
trauma training. It is recommended that trauma training be documented with new
9

employee training as it is due annually. Technical Assistance was provided in the
2019 Interim Report related to documentation of training under R 128.
RFCJJ Contract Oct 17: 2.10.p Page 19 AWOLP/escape Procedures
Training: The Contractor shall Provide quarterly training for staff regarding
facility AWOLP/escape protocols and measures to avoid AWOLP/escapes.
Six of six existing employee files and 14 of 15 new employee files did not contain
documentation of quarterly AWOL/escape procedures. Technical Assistance was
provided in the 2019 Interim Report related to documentation of training under R
128.
RFCJJ Contract Oct 17 Attachment A.2 Page 37 Psychiatric Consultation: In
a Juvenile Justice Mental Health and Behavioral Stabilization Program, the
youth shall have a comprehensive psychiatric consultation within 15
calendar days of the youth’s admission into the program. The consultation
shall include current and past psychiatric history, medical/developmental
history, social history, family history, mental status exam, medication
review, and a diagnosis and treatment recommendation.
One applicable current youth file did not contain a psychiatric consultation and the
referral was not done until 11/24/20 when the youth was admitted 09/29/20.
RFCJJ Contract Oct 17: 2.10.y.2)b) Page 26 Psychiatric Assessment:
b) Within 45 calendar days of the youth’s placement, the psychiatrist must
assess the youth and coordinate with the licensed clinical personnel
completing the psychosocial assessment. A review of the youth’s
medication history and current needs and prescription or adjustment of
medications and dosage as necessary must occur. Tele psychiatry may be
used when a local psychiatrist is not available.
One applicable current resident file did not contain a psychiatric assessment.
RFCJJ Contract Oct 17: 2.10.q – Page 19-20 Independent living preparation
activities shall be based on the results of the Casey Life Skills Assessment
that indicate an area of need. The Contractor shall identify independent living
activities in the youth’s treatment plan.
One applicable current resident file contained documentation that an initial Casey
Life Skills Assessment was completed but the records were not dated to confirm
timeframe. Additionally, there was no documentation of ongoing assessments
being completed. Per the facility ACE Casey Life Skills Policy, the Casey Life Skills
10

are given within 30 days of enrollment and when the student reaches stage 6 of
the program or one year - whichever comes first. The facility must begin to provide
documentation of the completion of the assessments inclusive of the dates to be
compliant.
RFCJJ Contract Oct 17: 2.9 Compliance Requirements
a. The Contractor must comply with requirements of MDHHS policies,
including, but not limited to, Juvenile Justice Residential (JRM), Services
Requirements Manual (SRM) and MDHHS policy amendments, including
interim policy bulletins and linked policies.
 CI 17-096 Treatment Plan Signatures: All treatment plans with a report
date of August 1, 2017, or later must have signatures from all
appropriate case members within 30 days of the report date.
One of five applicable current resident files reviewed was missing the youth’s
signature on one of the three treatment plans in the file.
IV. TECHNICAL ASSISTANCE
The facility was offered technical assistance in the following areas:
R 123 Education.
The facility is advised to ensure that all updated educational documents are filed
timely for verification of compliance.
R 142 Health services; policies and procedures.
The facility is advised to expand the documentation for diabetic youth’s blood glucose
level checks to include the attending nurse’s name and the time of the check.
R 150 Incident Reporting
The facility is advised to ensure that the DCWL consultant is advised of AWOLs,
which includes youth who do not return from passes. The current AWOL reporting
form does not have a prompt for this information, and it is recommended that it is
included to be in clear compliance.
V. CONSULTATION
The facility was offered consultation in the following areas:
Consultation was provided to the clinical staff related to discharge plan requirements
and treatment plans.
It is also recommended that the facility administrative team review the requirements
of the new MDHHS contract and ensure that staff at all levels are aware of the
changes. This could be documented in the training records.
11

VI. EVALUATION OF RENEWAL PERIOD
There were no substantiated incidents of maltreatment in care during this licensing
period.
There were no incidents of substantiated corporal punishment during this licensing
period.
The facility has submitted 1 acceptable corrective action plan not related to
maltreatment during this licensing period. This CAP was dated 03/29/21 and was
submitted in response to special investigation 2021C0201022. The facility was cited
as it was found that a diabetic youth did not receive his insulin timely. I reviewed
records of blood glucose monitoring and insulin administration for one of two diabetic
youth at the facility, for a random period of time, and found that the youth had been
tested regularly and insulin administrated as needed. I also interviewed one diabetic
youth who reported no issues or concerns with his diabetes testing or insulin
administration. It appears the facility is following their CAP in this area.
There are currently three pending/open special investigations which will be addressed
in the next inspection report if there are violations established.
VII. RECOMMENDATION
Based on inspection findings the facility is not in compliance with all applicable licensing
statutes and rules and/or MISEP requirements and/or contract/policy. Upon receipt of
an acceptable corrective action plan, it is recommended that the facility will be issued a
renewal of their regular license.
